H0.text: Wildcats are not related to house cats, explaining the significance of the 2004 discovery of an eight‑month‑old cat buried with its owner on Cyprus before Egyptian civilization.

H1.text: Cats were domesticated earlier than originally thought, as demonstrated by the 2004 discovery of an eight‑month‑old cat buried with its owner on the Mediterranean island of Cyprus, with the burial dating to a period before Egyptian civilization.

H2.text: Wildcats were not domesticated is the main significance of the 2004 discovery of an eight‑month‑old cat buried with its owner on Cyprus, a burial that predates Egyptian civilization and challenges the belief that the house cat was first tamed in ancient Egypt.

H3.text: The period of Egyptian civilization was older than originally thought, because the remains of an eight‑month‑old cat buried with its owner—discovered in 2004 on the Mediterranean island of Cyprus—date to a time before the previously accepted beginning of Egyptian civilization.

A4.text: Cats were not native to this area, which meant that the people must have brought cats to the island.

A5.text: Fragments of cat teeth and bone found at burial sites across the world have all been connected by DNA analysis to F.s. lybica, some dating to 7,000–8,000 years ago.
